awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: CIF: Medium: Group testing for Real-Time Polymerase Chain Reactions: From Primer Selection to Amplification Curve Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
Group testing is a screening technique that relies on careful combinatorial mixing and testing of batches of samples. By using group testing instead of individual testing, for most problem settings of practical interest, one is guaranteed significant savings in the number of tests performed and consequently, significant reductions in reporting delays and experimental costs. Group testing is especially desirable when monitoring the spread of infectious diseases such as Covid-19, which requires frequent examinations of massive populations. Although many ad-hoc approaches to group testing for infectious diseases have been put forward, little work has addressed the problem of end-to-end group-testing protocol design, which includes the selection of genetic regions for viral/bacterial identification, mathematical modeling and analysis of the test results and the development of guiding protocols for communal testing strategies. The overarching goals of the project are to determine which group-testing methods can actually mitigate the spread of Covid-19 and other diseases and to what extent, to estimate the reduction in the number of infected individuals achievable through the use of pooled real-time polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) tests, and to aid in the employment of Mobile Testing Units that can reach geographically remote regions. Other broader societal impacts include increased readiness for fighting future pandemics and training a new cohort of young researchers on interdisciplinary topics involving machine learning, coding theory and bioinformatics. 

The project aims to develop specialized machine-learning, combinatorial and information-theoretic methods for (a) identifying genomic regions with predictably low-mutation rates that may be used as amplification primers for gold-standard real-time polymerase chain reactions (RT-PCR) and determining best mixing strategies based on the likelihood of infection; (b) developing adequate models for amplification curves generated by RT-PCR and corresponding test-errors; (c) formulating experimental-protocol-specific non-adaptive and adaptive semiquantitative group testing schemes that account for nonbinary test outcomes; (d) addressing the testing issues associated with high-viral load subjects and heavy-hitter communities; and (e) integrating the mathematical techniques developed into an agent-based model for disease spreading and control in order to assess the potential impact of group testing and recommend effective test-quarantine-retest strategies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.

The rapid spread of infectious diseases, such as COVID-19, has highlighted the urgent need for efficient and scalable diagnostic testing strategies. Traditional approaches to testing, which often involve testing individuals one by one, are resource-intensive and can become impractical when large populations need frequent monitoring. Group testing offers a promising alternative by allowing multiple samples to be tested simultaneously in a combinatorial manner, significantly reducing the number of tests required while still accurately identifying infected individuals. Despite its potential, existing group testing techniques are primarily designed for binary outcomes (positive/negative) and do not fully utilize the semi-quantitative information available in many modern diagnostic techniques, such as real-time polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR).

 This research effort aimed to advance the field of group testing by developing new methodologies that leverage semi-quantitative data to improve testing efficiency and accuracy. By incorporating richer information from test results, such as varying levels of viral load, we sought to design testing schemes that outperform traditional approaches, especially in settings with a small number of infected individuals or clustered outbreaks. Our work also explored novel connections between group testing, combinatorial mathematics, and information theory, including the use of tropical arithmetic and graph-theoretic techniques, to provide deeper insights into the tradeoffs between the number of tests performed, decoding complexity, and testing accuracy. Through these advancements, we aimed to enhance the ability to detect and control infectious disease outbreaks, while also contributing to the broader theoretical foundations of group testing and related disciplines.

 Our research yielded several significant theoretical advancements in the field of group testing, particularly in the development of nearly optimal semi-quantitative schemes and the exploration of new parameter regimes for both adaptive and non-adaptive settings. One of our key findings was the existence of nearly optimal semi-quantitative group testing schemes in settings where Ct (cycle threshold) values from RT-PCR tests were used to distinguish varying viral loads. Although a major challenge in this setting is that the Ct values of certain infected individuals can mask those of others, we were able to design schemes that not only accounted for this masking effect but also outperformed the information-theoretic lower bound for binary group testing when the number of infected individuals was small. This surprising result demonstrates the potential of semi-quantitative information to achieve efficiencies beyond traditional group testing methods. In the context of adaptive group testing, we further showed that it is possible to construct schemes that outperform the information-theoretic lower bound for binary group testing across any number of infected individuals. By leveraging the ability to sequentially update testing strategies based on previous results, we developed methods that significantly reduce the number of tests needed while maintaining high accuracy in identifying infected individuals. These results suggest that adaptive strategies can offer substantial improvements over non-adaptive counterparts, particularly when rich, semi-quantitative data are available.

 Additionally, we made important contributions to the theory of non-adaptive binary group testing, where the testing strategy is fixed in advance. We demonstrated that it is possible to identify a uniformly random subset of k infected individuals from a population of n using only \ln(2 - 4\epsilon)^{-2} k \ln n tests, with a decoding complexity of O(\epsilon^{-2} k \ln n) for any small \epsilon > 0. This result was achieved by utilizing Mobius transformations and generating functions, allowing for a more refined analysis of the tradeoffs between the number of tests and the decoding complexity. These findings expand the range of achievable parameters in non-adaptive group testing and provide new insights into the efficiency limits of combinatorial testing.
